8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). I was 11 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? came with my family

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) My uncle, Robert Jaques talked my father into going west. He had gone west to Kellorgrass three years before and was in love with the country so he talked my father into leaving the sailing and to go west.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

I think my grandfather thought we were crazy but later on in 1904 he came west and my grandmother and homesteaded (he was 76 then). He died before completing his three years but Dad got the quarter it is still in the family, my brother Clyde farms it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Family

13. What means of transportation did you use? C.P.R. train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

There were many Indians in and around Moose Jaw at that time. I can remember them squatting on the side walks in their bright shawls and leather clothing on the men.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan at another uncle's nest? Jaques who came out as a very young man to work on the Crow Nest, Jaques part of the railway was just going in. He arrived at Moose Jaw with 75¢ in his pocket enough for supper, bed and breakfast. He left at dawn with a bunch of workers for the Crow Nest. Later homesteading at Buffalo Lake, where we went first.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Dad filled on the homestead on March 17th, 1902.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We lived there all the time, my brother still lives on the Old homestead, he farms 480 acres, Dad's quarter Grandpa's Quarter and a quarter Dad bought. Dad's homestead was 22-14-42a, N.E. ¼.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? Broughooses running away, lack of water, loneliness. We were the FIRST settlers in the district now known as Briercroft. We drove out from Moose Jaw in the district now gone store in Moose Jaw. Sometimes they wrote a letter in to see if there was no station there at that time, so they were just dropped off in a big box there at my father or Bruce went to Drinkwater on the P.R. There was no bridge there so they'd walk a plank on top load them on to the wagons and drive about 10 miles home. That's the way we got our groceries for the first two years.

There were no schools or churches or people, just us, but buggy loads of land seekers start coming in, then they'll make a line for our place, my people fed them free. (Can you imagine that) scores and dozens of them, gradually the little settlement grew a lot of batchelors, built little shacks but in about five years there were other families coming in.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? We visited the Coventry settlement now and then, about 8 miles from us toward Moose Jaw, Went to church in someone's house I remember.

Frances Coventry and his brothers formed a little settlement, they had a school house, and there was a bridge over the river there. They were very good to us, as I recall.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? Broughoes running away, lack of water, loneliness. We were the FIRST settlers in the district now known as Briercrest. We drove out from Moose Jaw with a team of broughoes on a lumber wagon. Sometimes they wrote a letter in to say what no station there at that time, so they were just dropped off in a big box there was no bridge there so they'd walk a plank on top of the CPR dam and walk a mile carry our groceries on their backs load them on to the wagon and drive about 10 miles hole. That's the way we got our groceries for the first two years.

There were no schools or churches or people, just us, but scores and dozens of families started coming and they all made a bee line for our place. We had a school house and church and they all thought that there were other families coming in.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? We visited the Coventry settlement now and then about 8 miles from us toward Moose Jaw. Went to church in someone's house I remember.

Frances Coventry and his brothers formed a little settlement, they had a school house and there was a bridge over the river there. They were very good to us, as I recall.
25. When was the first car used in the community? My father had the first car, and Overland, he got it in 1911, the year the C.N.R., railway came.

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Dad bought it in Moose Jaw, although there was no one to share, gas lights that shined your eyebrows off every time he lit it.

28. Where was your dwelling nearest the town line? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. Did you continue to trade there? Then a store was built in Drinkwater dam so they could drive over it and draw grain after an elevator was built, and so someone had grain to sell. The going was very slow at first, as frost seemed to get the wheat every year.

30. How often did you shop in the early days? about once a month.

25. Was the first car used in the community? My father had the first car, an Oldsmobile, he got it in 1911. The year the C.N.R. railway came.

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What make?

Dad bought it in Moose Jaw. It was a four seater with no cop, four doors, a horn, although there was no one to start, gas lights that singed your eyebrows off every time he lit it.

27. Where was the trading center for tax from your house?

Moose Jaw, 35 miles away. Then a store was built in Drinkwater about 1911, continued to trade there. (Indicates any changes due to new towns, sayings, better means of travel, etc.)

28. Dad wrote to Ottawa and a bridge was built just above the C.P.R. dam, so they could drive over it and draw grain after an elevator was built and someone had grain to sell. The gohr was very slow at first, as frost seemed to get the wheat every year.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

About once a month.

30. When did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? After the railway came in, in 1911.

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

We never used the mail order houses very much, Dad thought the small store keepers needed money to keep going, so we bought mainly all our stuff from the local stores. Moose Jaw had usually as Briarcrest never had any women's clothing, neither had Drinkwater, only men's overalls, shoes, socks, wind breakers, etc., just rough clothing.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

I think it was about 1908. Dad got that started too. He needed a certain number of subscribers and had to talk an old demon when into it. She was afraid of it and slept in the barn until a thunder storm came. When you came to Drinkwater the first time was it worth buying permanent life? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

**Mr. Dad** just intended to stay three years but he stayed a lifetime, around 36 years I think.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons?

A lot of bachelors got out, they were too lonely but it was a beautiful rich district, good soil and good crops and most of them (the homesteaders) lived and died there. Now their sons and grandsons farm the homesteads.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return? Not many, they swept it out. Some of the young men went to war but every one of them came home (think God) and all said they never wanted to leave the country again as long as they lived.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Mad was a J.A., all his life, a post master, Bruce Jaques my brother has been on the council for twenty years. We all worked for the church. Dad held the first school built, the first Masonic Lodge chartered, the first store, the first church, the first school board, the church board, the first store in the town. He sold it to Horatio, a relative from Ont.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I don't remember the first dates.

Dad had the first post office too, about 1904 I think, he made a little pigeon hole XXXX on a partition in their bedroom that was the first post office, after we drove to Drinkwater for the mail once a week. Tuesdays, after that twice a week, Dad put up a little store right on the farm and run it for about five years did a roaring business too, as it was a kind of half way house between Drinkwater and the Dirt hills and the country beyond.

My mother named our farm Briercroft. We were driving along a trail and came to a tiny hill, she said to Dad, that's what we'll call our farm, Briercroft, because the hill was covered with brier roses. When the railroad came they asked us for the name for the nearest town.
